citations.narrative:
In the back enclosures housing the sheep, goats and llamas, there was loose cyclone fencing on the ground, along with
broken wooden fence posts. The alley where the herd of animals moves through between the public space and the back
enclosure had damaged fencing and a plywood shed with holes and sharp points. In the adjacent enclosure housing a
llama, there were multiple holes in the fencing, with broken wooden fence panels as well. Loose and broken fencing
creates sharp points and potential for the animals to get injured, outdoor housing facilities shall be maintained in good
repair to protect the animals from injury.
Correct by 15 May 24

The young bear "Betty" had been moved into the den adjacent to the adult male bear two weeks before inspection, and
had only been out of the den/shelter once since mid-April. The den/shelter is approximately the size of a small car interior
and does not provide sufficient space to allow a 2 year old bear to make normal postural and social adjustments with
adequate freedom of movement. The rectangular den is barely wider than the bear is long, forcing her to bend to turn
around. The inspector waited until the facility was closed to observe this bear being allowed out into the outdoor
enclosure, which she spent less than a minute visible outside her den in a fifteen minute time period. She appeared
nervous as she left the den briefly and according to the facility she was shocked by the hot wire and returned to her den.
The facility is only allowing her supervised time as she acclimates to the open topped outdoor enclosure and learns the
hotwire. She has not yet been introduced to the adult male, who spends his day outside, although the goal is to house the
bears together with shared outdoor space and individual dens. Enclosures shall be constructed and maintained so as to
provide sufficient space to allow each animal to make normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of
movement.
Correct by providing adequate space for a young bear by 27 May 2024.

In the pond area housing swans, ducks and geese, there are multiple holes in the footing adjacent to the water where the
wire has broken. Floors should protect the birds' feet and legs from injury, and multiple holes where feet and legs could go
through can cause injury to the birds.
Correct by 15 May 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
